field_reports.summary: MNG: Storm Surge - 07-2025 - Severe Wind Storm-Flash Rainfall
field_reports.description:
On the night of 24–25 July 2025, Mongolia was struck by a sudden severe windstorm reaching up to 33 m/s, followed by short but intense rainfall, hailstorms, and thunderstorms. The event caused widespread damage across 15 locations in Ulaanbaatar, Sukhbaatar Province, and Tuv Province, severely impacting household dwellings, public infrastructure, and essential services.

The most extensive damage was recorded in Songinokhairkhan District, Ulaanbaatar, where 113 traditional homes collapsed, including two rendered completely uninhabitable. In addition, 60 fences and 9 vehicles were damaged, two kindergartens lost parts of their roofs, and four residents sustained minor injuries. Power outages were reported in five khoroos, with 13 utility poles downed, including four in the 32nd khoroo where electricity remains cut off.

In Sukhbaatar Province, the soums of Halzan, Uulbayan, and Tumentsogt experienced heavy rainfall and strong winds. Khalzan received up to 65 mm of rain and reported damage to 27 traditional homes, 20 fences, and 3 house roofs, along with the collapse of a flood embankment that led to the inundation of five households. Playground equipment, greenhouses, and sanitation facilities were destroyed, and multiple vehicles became stuck in mud. Uulbayan and Tumentsogt reported additional household losses and vehicle damage.

In Tuv Province, storm activity affected Bayankhangai, Argalant, Lun, Erdenesant, and Zuunmod soums, with some areas experiencing hail. Over 80 traditional houses collapsed across these locations. Public structures, including school dormitories, kitchens, and bathhouses, were damaged. In Lun soum, a fallen 35kV transmission pole led to a power outage affecting 483 customers, including businesses and households. Livestock deaths and widespread fence destruction were also reported.

field_reports.description:
Between 11:00 PM and 3:00 AM on April 10–11, 2025, a severe dust storm struck Erdene soum (sub-administration unit) in Govi-Altai province, causing widespread destruction. Initial assessment reported that more than 120 gers (traditional houses) were destroyed and the roofs of 18 buildings were torn off.

The collapse of 4 to 5 power poles led to a complete disruption of electricity across the soum.

As of 15 April, a total of 184 households have been affected. Additionally, the roofs of 9 buildings belonging to businesses and organizations were damaged or collapsed. While there has been a significant number of livestock deaths, the full extent of the damage remains unconfirmed due to ongoing issues with electricity and communication. 

The most severely affected facility was the local school, where the entire roof was blown off, making it impossible to continue educational activities.

results.summary:
Between 11:00 PM and 3:00 AM on April 10–11, 2025, a severe dust storm swept through Erdene soum (sub-administration unit) of Govi-Altai province. Initial reports indicate that over 120 households' gers (traditional houses) were destroyed and the roofs of 18 buildings were torn off.

Due to the collapse of 4 to 5 power poles, electricity supply has been disrupted across the soum.

There are no confirmed detailed figures or reports of casualties at this time.
results.name: MNG: Storm Surge - 04-2025 - Dust storm

field_reports.description: A wildfire started on 9 March 2025 in the eastern region of Mongolia, affecting Dornod, Khentii, and Sukhbaatar provinces. The fire continues to spread across the region, impacting 11 locations. Response efforts are being led by the local emergency management agency. As of 10 March 2025, a total of 66 households have been affected, with homes, animals, animal shelters, and other assets damaged or destroyed. A local emergency has been declared, lasting until June 2025, with the local emergency operation center in Dornod province (that has been affected the most) province activated to contain the fire and support the affected population. As a member of the State emergency commission, the National Society's local branches are working closely with authorities and communities to assess the needs and losses of those affected.

field_reports.description: Between October 11 and 14, a series of steppe fires erupted across 16 hectares in various locations within the Dornod and Sukhbaatar provinces of eastern Mongolia. Subsequently, from October 15 to 16, the fires spread to Khentii province. Tragically, two children under the age of five were found deceased, and one herder sustained severe burns. The fires destroyed six homes and resulted in the loss of over 1,000 livestock, along with significant damage to animal shelters, hay, fodder, and vehicles. In total, 76 individuals from 21 families have been directly affected, and six locations are currently without power.

field_reports.summary: MNG: Flood - 06-2024 - Flood in Ulaanbaatar No.1
field_reports.description:
According to the government authorities, due to continuous rainfall in the Capital city of Ulaanbaatar Mongolia from June 18 to June 22, the water levels of the Terelj (northwest), Tuul, Selbe, and Dund rivers rose, reaching 18-82 cm above the dangerous flood level and resulting in the flood situation in the city. As a result, some gers/yurts, houses, apartments, cars, and yards have been flooded in some districts in UB, including Bayanzurkh, Bayangol, Bagakhangai, Sukhbaatar, Songino-Khairkhan, Nalaikh, and Khan-Uul districts and the flooded roads are covered in mud/dirt. According to the Capital Emergency Operation Center, 77,397 families, entities and organizations in UB have experienced power outages, for whom power has been restored for 75,412 as of June 22. 

According to NAMEM, heavy rain is expected to occur in most regions of the country in the upcoming 5 days including Ulaanbaatar city.

As a result, some gers/yurt, houses, apartments, cars, and yards have been flooded in some districts in UB, including Bayanzurkh, Bayangol, Sukhbaatar, Songino-Khairkhan, Nalaikh, and Khan-Uul districts. field_reports.description: According to the local government and local Red Cross Branch's initial assessment, an hour-long heavy rain occurred in the central area of Zavkhan province, Mongolia on 17 June 2024 resulting in flash floods. Initial assessments revealed that 449 people from 158 families have been affected, 18 families have been evacuated to safer places and 25 trapped individuals have been rescued. There are 45 families have been reported as displaced and evacuated to the temporary shelter, 4 residential streets, 26 house yards, 10 gers (Mongolian traditional houses), and 8 built houses have been flooded. Two children who went missing were found and no information on the number of injured or dead have been reported.

field_reports.summary: MNG: Chemical Emergency - 01-2024 - Gas explosion in Urban area
field_reports.description:
At 1:25 AM on January 24, 2024, a gas truck exploded on Dunjingarav Street, 26th Khoroo, Bayanzurkh District, Ulaanbaatar City, Mongolia, due to a slippery road condition. The incident impacted a 30-40 meter area, specifically affecting the 207th Apartment, housing 63 households (257 people including 78 children). Regrettably, three firefighters lost their lives, and 15 individuals, including three children, were hospitalized. Additionally, 61 people, including 17 children and three infants, were evacuated to the hotel and 136th Elementary School in Bayanzurkh District. The remaining 135 displaced people are staying with relatives and friends. 

As of January 24, 12 PM, local authorities have successfully contacted 196 families, while 1 family remains unreachable. The National Police Office has temporarily closed main roads within 200-500 meters around the affected area for an indefinite period to ensure public safety.

According to the Red Cross Branch from the field report, as of January 25, there are three temporary shelters provided to the affected people. The number of displaced people has increased to 157 including 113 adults, 10 elderlies (age 57-84), 1 disabled, 6 pregnant women, and 44 children (age 1-17) staying at the temporary shelter. The cost for people at the hotel as temporary shelters is being covered by the State Emergency Commission. 

As of January 29, there are a total of 173 displaced people including 53 children and a foreign citizen at the three evacuation centers. The remaining displaced people are being contacted by the Local emergency operation center for registration. The Bayanzurkh Red Cross Branch is coordinating humanitarian assistance in the evacuation centers.

At 1:25 AM on January 24, 2024, a gas truck exploded on Dunjingarav Street, 26th Khoroo, Bayanzurkh District, Ulaanbaatar City, Mongolia, due to a slippery road condition. The incident impacted a 30-40 meter area, specifically affecting the 207th Apartment, housing 63 households (200 people). Regrettably, three firefighters lost their lives, and 15 individuals, including three children, were hospitalized. Additionally, 61 people, including 17 children and three infants, were evacuated to the hotel and 136th Elementary School in Bayanzurkh District. As of 8 AM, local authorities have successfully contacted 196 families, while 1 family remains unreachable. The National Police Office has temporarily closed main roads within 200-500 meters around the affected area for an indefinite period to ensure public safety.

field_reports.summary: MNG: Cold Wave - 11-2023 - Coldwave and Snowstorm #2 (2024-01-17)
field_reports.description:
According to NEMA, between 3-5 November, the air temperature dropped by -10-15 degrees, and 0.0-8.0 mm of snow fell in the East, West, North, South, and Central parts of the country including Gobi-Altai, Khovd, Uvs, Zavkhan, Arkhangai, Uvurkhangai, Tuv, Bulgan, Selenge, Khentii, Dornod, Sukhbaatar, Dundgobi, and Dornogobi provinces. Wind speed reached 16-22 m/s causing a strong snowstorm that lasted about 5-15 hours. Early warnings were issued 2nd of November by NEMA.  Due to the hazardous snowstorm, 37 out of 46 people who went missing while driving or herding have been rescued, 42 vehicles and 113 individuals have been evacuated to a safe place by the NEMA search and rescue team in 10 locations of 8 provinces including Khovd, Uvs, Zavkhan, Arkhangai, Tuv, Uvurkhangai, Selenge, and Dornod provinces. 8 casualties including 1 child have been reported in Tuv and Uvurkhangai provinces. According to NAMEM, another snowstorm is expected to occur between the 6 and 7th of this month in the West, North, and Central parts of the country and the second early warning has been issued by NEMA on the 6th.

Due to the situation, the State Emergency Commission released an order to establish an Emergency Working Group (EWG) led by the Deputy Chief of NEMA to monitor the winter situation and take necessary action on 8 November 2023 at NEMA headquarters to operate nationwide. The EWG consists of representatives from the Ministry of Health (MOH), Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Light Industry (MOFALI), Ministry of Road and Transport Development (MRTD), Ministry of Mining and Heavy Industry, Ministry of Energy, Ministry of Digital Development and Communications, Ministry of Labour and Social Protection, Mineral Resources and Petroleum Authority, General Authority for Veterinary Services, National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring (NAMEM), and Mongolian Red Cross Society. 

According to NAMEM, the third early warning of snowstorm was issued on November 16th, and a heavy snowstorm occurred on November 21st night in Bulgan, Selenge, Tuv, Uvurkhangai, Dundgovi, Umnugovi, Khentii, Dornod, Sukhbaatar, and Dornogov provinces. The road access has been closed from Khentii provincial to Berkh village, and the road access from Baruun-Urt soum in Sukhbaatar provinces on November 22 for 13 hours, due to the snowstorm. A total of 333 people who went missing were rescued by the NEMA search and rescue team in 27 soums (soum is the second level of administration unit under the province) of Sukhbaatar, Dornod, Khentii, and Dornogovi provinces, and one casualty has been reported in Dorgovi province while herding. 

On November 27, another snowstorm occurred in some parts of Zavkhan, Khuvsgul, Arkhangai, and Uvurkhangai provinces, and 6 out of 40 vehicles stuck in the snow were rescued by the NEMA search and rescue team in Zavkhan province. The relevant government agencies are taking immediate action to clean the road for safeties is ongoing.  

Next snowstorms were expected to occur in the East, West, and Northern parts of the country between November 28-30, and air temperature is expected to reach (-24C) - (-30C) Celsius. 

NAMEM has issued early warnings on heavy snow and dust storms that are taking place for this week in western, central, and southern parts of the country, and were expected to reach 18-24m/sec as of December 1.  

As of December 4, a strong wind has started from 3 AM in Khovd, Uvs, Zavkhan, Bayan-Ulgii, Govi-Altai (west), and Khuvsgul (north)  provinces speeding up to 10-38m/sec. Due to the storm, a total of 1672 people are out of power at 3 locations in Khovd province, and the entire region of Govi-Altai provinces (population 58,735, source: National Statistics Office, 2022). Local authorities are taking immediate action to restore power is ongoing. After the local action, the same night, 12 out of 18 soums' power has been restored and 6 soums are having power outages where approximately 14,894 people live. Road access from and to Zavkhan (west) province has been closed due to the storms and it is not possible to take any action from the government during the storms. An emergency working group led by NEMA is monitoring the situation and preparing to take action. 

It is forecasted that the next snowstorm is expected to occur between December 6-9 in western, eastern, northern, and central parts of the country reaching the speed of 14-20m/sec. The early warnings have been issued by NAMEM, NEMA, and the MRCS in the target regions through social media and mass messaging. 

This Autumn, snow fell in early November, and as of November 10, more than 57 percent of the country has been covered by snow, in comparison with the previous year (snow cover was 11 percent of the country by November 8, 2022) it is 5 times more this year. 

As of November 27, snow thickness is 50cm in the West, and 20-40cm in the Central part of the country including Tuv, Dornogovi, Dornod, Khentii, Uvs, Zavkhan, and Khovd provinces. In a normal summer year, when the average thickness of snow covering the dominant pasture reaches 12-15 cm in the steppe region, 8-10cm in the mountainous region, and 5-6cm in the Gobi region, it is challenging for animals to feed.

Dzud risk map was produced by NAMEM on November 10, more than 50 percent of the country is at high risk (9 percent at highest, 45 percent at high risk), 40 percent is at moderate, while only 10 percent is at low dzud risk. 

Dzud risk is high in Gobi and Western regions due to drought, low precipitation in summer, and high frequency of snowstorms across the country. However, Eastern and Central parts of the country experienced a good summer, the risk was significantly increased due to heavy snowfall and snowstorms in early November, causing a hard winter and spring for herder communities. The current winter situation is increasing vulnerability because of weak livestock, heavy snow-covered pastures, compacted snow surface, extreme coldness, and lack of cash for herders while there is limited market to sell livestock in the high-risk dzud areas.

As of November 30, the second Dzud risk map has been shared by NAMEM. According to the updated Dzud risk map, high-risk areas have been increased to 70% (26% is at high highest risk, 43% is at high risk), 26% is at moderate, and only 5% is at low risk of Dzud. Most parts of Uvs (west), Sukhbaatar (east), and Dornogovi (south) provinces, and some parts of Bayan-Ulgii, Khovd, Zavkhan, Govi-Altai (west), Arkhangai (central), Umnugobi (south), Dornod (east) provinces are at highest risk of Dzud. 

Due to the worsening situation, the EWG has been extended to activate as an Emergency Operation Center (EOC) co-led by the Vice Minister of Food, Agriculture, and Ligh Industry including more government agencies in compliance with the SEC order on 8 December 2023.

NAMEM has issued early warnings on heavy snow and dust storms that are taking place for this week in the western, central, and southern regions of the country, and the wind speed was expected to reach 18-24m/sec as of December 1. It is anticipated that the snowstorms may worsen the current winter conditions. 

The forecasted snowstorms occurred on 4 and 7 December 2023 with a speed of 15-28m/s in most parts of the country with no casualties reported but contributing to the current snow coverage and snow thickness. 

According to NAMEM, the latest Dzud risk map was released on 20 December 2023, indicating that 57% of the country is in very high-risk of Dzud, 90% of the country is in high-risk of Dzud, including 89 soums of 15 provinces in Dzud condition, 63 soums of 14 provinces are near Dzud condition, and 5 soums of 2 provinces are in Black Dzud condition. By the end of December 2023, the risk has been increased to affect 165 soums (330 soums in total) of 20 provinces, and Baganuur – a remote district of Ulaanbaatar city is in high or very high risk of Dzud condition. 

In addition to that, the fuel shortage occurred from mid-November to the end of December. According to the Ministry of Energy, the shortages occurred due to the reduction of supply to restrict the electricity consumption of consumers for three hours a day in the capital Ulaanbaatar City, and 150 soums. Fuel shortages created additional constraints to the harsh winter conditions restricting transportation and even the major Mining companies were near to disfunction. For instance, the main hay and fodder producer Dornod province was unable to transport the hay and fodder supply due to the fuel outage during this period, resulting in delays of hay and fodder supply during this critical period. This led the herder communities to utilize the traditional way of transportation such as horse-drawn carriage.

According to the EOC assessment, currently, there are 60,511 herder households or 217,309 people in very high-risk of Dzud areas. In which, 18,859 herder households or 67,892 people are on otor movement ((otor movement happens when herdsmen are forced to leave their winter places to seek better pasture due to the harsh winter condition). Based on the EOC assessment, there are 98 pregnant women, 1188 children under the age of 5, 580 elderly people, 220 disabled people, 589 people with a chronic underlying disease in the otor movement, and many more left residing soum center by the first week of January 2024. 

Considering the previous year's Dzud risk map released by NAMEM on 10 January 2018, 50% of the country was covered by snow, where 66 soums of 12 provinces were in Dzud risk, 41 soums of 14 provinces in near Dzud condition, eventually resulting in 18 billion MNT loss to the Mongolian economy.  While in 2020-2021 winter, the Dzud risk map as of 10 January 2021, indicated that over 50 % of the territory was identified with severe winter risk, while 25 % of the area is in mid-risk. Eight provinces have over 20 % of very high-risk coverage in the territory. IFRC, through Anticipatory Action, provided Mongolian provinces with cash assistance, livestock, and nutrition kits. In particular, the Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF) of IFRC released CHF 210,968 to assist 1,000 vulnerable herder families to prevent starvation, dehydration, and cold exposure of their livestock because of poor access to feed, water, veterinary care, and shelter. 

According to the 1 February 2023 Dzud risk map, 35% of the country was at very high risk of Dzud, 41% at high risk of Dzud, and over 20% was at moderate risk of Dzud. Whereas the 20 December 2023 Dzud risk map this year indicated that 90% of the country is at high risk of Dzud, with 57% at very high risk of Dzud 23% at high risk, and 10% is in moderate risk of Dzud. 

The intensity and severity of Dzud risk for this year is the most severe compared to the previous years since 2015. 

Considering the historical data, the peak of livestock mortality occurs from March to April. Therefore January through February is a critical period for herder communities to protect their livelihood from the potential risk of mass mortaity or loss of livelihood.

field_reports.description:
The NAMEM has issued several early warnings on snow storms from 10 Feb 2024 that the occurrence of the hazardous storms reaching the maximum speed of 34 m/s in the west, south, central, and east parts of the country. Between 13-17 Feb 2024, there have been a total of 5 heavy snowstorms that occurred in 15 provinces, intensifying the current Dzud/coldwave condition for herder communities directly affecting 251 people and 1 casualty, 42 missing people have been reported as of 17 Feb 2024. From this, 230 people including 63 children, and 81 vehicles that were blocked by the storm have been rescued by the search and rescue team. According to NEMA, there are 3 house roofs, 30 fences, and 7 vehicle windows that have been severely damaged in Govi-Altai (west) province. Regarding the heavy snowstorms, road access between the Capital city in six directions has been closed including Uvurkhangai (central), Umnugovi (south gobi), Dungovi (south), Khentii, Dornod, and Sukhbaatar (east) between 17-18 February 2024 as a preventative measure. 

As of the first half of February 2024, the maximum snow thickness is 46cm, the maximum precipitation (snowfall) is 17mm in the west, the air temperature is minimum (-16.6) and maximum (-42) Celsius in the western and central parts of the country. The livestock mortality rate has reached 611,914, and 14,707 herder households are on the Otor movement (internal migration) by 09 February 2024. Additionally, EOC is unable to open road access to 13,573 herder households in remote areas, requiring the government's efforts to clear 38,444-kilometer roads as of 15 February 2024. Ongoing government efforts were made to clear the 23,451-kilometer roads that were blocked by snow. However, the snowstorms and heavy snowfall intensifies the government efforts. 

Due to the intensified Dzud/coldwave impact, the Mongolian government has declared a heightened level (second level of Dzud Disaster) of Dzud/coldwave Disaster Readiness nationwide on 14 Feb 2024. The EOC is developing a heightened level of response procedures for the relevant agencies.

According to NAMEM, another snowstorm is expected to occur between the 6 and 7th of this month in the West, North, and Central part of the country and the second early warning have been issued by NEMA on the 6th.

According to NAMEM, the third early warning of snow-storm issued on November 16th, and a heavy snowstorm occurred on November 21st night in Bulgan, Selenge, Tuv, Uvurkhangai, Dundgovi, Umnugovi, Khentii, Dornod, Sukhbaatar, and Dornogov provinces. The road access has been closed from Khentii provincial to Berkh village, and the road access from Baruun-Urt soum in Sukhbaatar provinces on November 22 for 13 hours, due to the snowstorm. A total of 333 people who went missing were rescued by the NEMA search and rescue team in 27 soums of Sukhbaatar, Dornod, Khentii, and Dornogovi provinces, and one casualty has been reported in Dorgovi province while herding. 

On November 27, another snow-storm occurred in some parts of Zavkhan, Khuvsgul, Arkhangai, and Uvurkhangai provinces, and 6 out of 40 vehicles stuck in the snow were rescued by the NEMA search and rescue team in Zavkhan province. The relevant government agencies are taking immediate action to clean the road for safeties is ongoing.  

Next snowstorms are expected to occur in the East, West, and Northern parts of the country between November 28-30, and air temperature is expected to reach (-24C) - (-30C) Celsius. 

NAMEM has issued early warnings on heavy snow and dust storms that are taking place for this week in western, central, and southern parts of the country, and were expected to reach 18-24m/sec as of December 1.  

As of December 4, a strong wind has started from 3 AM in Khovd, Uvs, Zavkhan, Bayan-Ulgii, Govi-Altai (west), and Khuvsgul (north)  provinces speeding up to 10-38m/sec. Due to the storm, a total of 1672 people are out of power at 3 locations in Khovd province, and the entire region of Govi-Altai provinces (population 58,735, source: National Statistics Office, 2022). Local authorities are taking immediate action to restore power is ongoing. After the local action, the same night, 12 out of 18 soums' power has been restored and 6 soums are having power outages where approximately 14,894 people live. Road access from and to Zavkhan (west) province has been closed due to the storms and it is not possible to take any action from the government during the storms. An emergency working group led by NEMA is monitoring the situation and preparing to take action. 

It is forecasted that the next snowstorms will occur between December 6-9 in western, eastern, northern, and central parts of the country reaching the speed of 14-20m/sec. The early warnings have been issued by NAMEM, NEMA, and the MRCS in the target regions through social media and mass messaging.

field_reports.description:
As of July 14, due to prolonged rainfall between July 3-12, In Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, pluvial floods damaged 96 gers, 32 houses, 199 apartments, 3 bridges, 2 dams, 7 mainroads, 6 electric transmission poles partially. The flood caused powercut for 29913 people and as of July 14, 1090 people are still under powercut. Due to floods, 743 people were evacuated to temporary shelters. 

As of July 14, in 10 provinces including Darkhan-Uul, Zavkhan, Uvurkhangai, Dornogovi, Arkhangai, Selenge, Govi-sumber, Tuv, Dundgovi, Khuvsgul, pluvial floods affected 1956 people in which 1245 people were evacuated to temporary shelters. As of July 14, there are 213 people are at temporary shelter (Uvurkhangai 103, Darkhan-Uul 94, Zavkhan 6, Selenge 10). Number of affected infrastructure and gers are being verified at the moment.

results.summary:
Between July 3-5, rainfall of 28.4 mm have occured in 26 hours in central area of Mongolia including Ulaanbaatar. Prolonged rainfall has increased the water level of rivers by 10-30 cm from average height.  Selbe and Dund rivers run across Ulaanbaatar city and due to rainfall, both rivers are flooding and affecting the apartments nearby. The dam for the Selbe river has collapsed due to the overflooding. As of July 5, 54 apartments, 1 garage of mall, 5 houses, 15 gers, 2 main roads, 2 tunnels are in standing water caused by flood and 397 staff are working at the affected sites by draining the water with suction pumps. National Emergency Management has assisted 526 people including the elderly, disabled people and children who had been isolated by the standing water and flood and 306 vehicles have been moved from the flooded areas. In the flooded apartments, there's an electricity blackout and people are evacuating from their apartments.

Meanwhile in the ger district, there are households who are affected by the flash floods in Bayanzurkh, Chingeltei districts. Main concern is flooded pit latrines which is increasing the risk of contagious and water-borne diseases. The number of affected houses are being verified by the RC branches and will update the report once it's verified. 

The rain is expected to continue until July 10.
results.name: MNG: Flood - 2023-07 - Urban floods

field_reports.summary: MNG: Epidemic - 2023-06 - Bubonic plague confirmed case
field_reports.description:
West Mongolia's Govi-Altai Province has been quarantined for a week due to a suspected case of bubonic plague, also known as the Black Death, said the provincial governor's office on Tuesday. Relevant authorities identified 62 individuals who made physical contact with the suspected person and placed under quarantine. The PCR test has been sent to regional health center in Khovd province and the result is expected to come on July 28, 2023. The suspected case has been reported in Bugat soum (administrative subdivision) of the province, and is now under isolation at a local hospital, the office said in a statement.
As of June 29th, the case has been confirmed by the laboratory test, out of 62 people who made physical contact with the confirmed case, no one is showing any symptom now. The body condition of the confirmed case is recovering. The emergency commission will gather at 13 PM on June 29 to discuss whether to lift the quarantine or extend it.

field_reports.summary: MNG: Cold Wave - 2023-05 - Snow and dust storm #2 (2023-05-20)
field_reports.description: Devastating snow storm swept across eastern parts of Mongolia including Dornod, Sukhbaatar, Khentii provinces and certain provinces in Gobi areas starting from around 06:00 AM on May 19, 2023 throughout the day and night until around 13:00 PM of May 20, 2023. Average speed was 18-20 m/s and it reached 28-30  m/s at some point, according to the National Agency for Meterogoloy and Environmental Monitoring. Due to the storm, 120 people went missing mostly from herder community and 104 people have been found meanwhile 15 people are still missing and 1 person from Bayankhutag, Khentii province have been found dead. There have been severe infrastructural damage, accomodation and livestock loss, transportation delay caused by the storm. The complete damage hasn't been compiled and verified yet, known losses include complete loss of accomodation of 36 households, roughly 100 households had their gers and houses partially damaged, 156 households had their fences completely destroyed. Loss of livestock is estimated to be around 150,000 - 200,000 and soon to be verified. Using of the eastern main road was prohibited as the safety measure by the government on starting from 8:00 AM on May 19, 2023 and now (May 20, 2023) has been returned to normal. Several sub-stations have been damaged and fell down due to the strong wind causing power outage in several counties in Dornod, Sukhbaatar, Khentii provinces.

field_reports.description: Violent storms are sweeping across western Mongolia with heavy precipitation starting from May 5th to current period (May 8, 23). According to Khovd provincial emergency commission, the snow height has reached 80-120 cm in the mountanous areas, at least 40 cm in the steppe areas completely isolating (disabling the all means of transportation) Duut, Munkhkhairkhan , Zereg, Darvi soums. On May 7, a herder household was affected by the storm and 18 staff from local emergency managemnet agency worked for 18 hours to rescue the household members and took them to the hospital. Due to the isolation from the snow, about 350 households can no longer take their herd on pasture and their livestock are being exposed to cold and malnourishment. Eventually, the malnourishment and cold exposure are expected to be become issue for the herders themselves. In the affected population, there are about 72 disabled person, 480 children and 21 pregnant women.

field_reports.description:
According to the State Emergency Commission, wildfire started in Erdenetsagaan county of Sukhbaatar province in Mongolia on April 8th has currently (as of April 12) spread in Khalkhgol, Gurvanzagal, Choibalsan, Matad soums in Dornod province. The intensifying factors of the wildfires include the strong wind (12 - 19 sec/m) and geographical character (both Sukhbaatar and Dornod are eastern provinces which are mainly grasslands). Team of 250 people including local state staff (additional forces joined from neighboring provinces which are Khentii and Sukhbaatar provinces) and community members headed by the Provincial emergency management agency worked on-site to distinguish the fire, latter, the team was strengthened by the National Rescue Brigade experts. It's currently impossible to precisely estimate the loss of natural resources, livestock, human assets and will take more time. Known losses include 42 acres if forest land and 202,847 acres of grassland burnt,  15 households lost their gers/houses. The State emergency commission allocated gers to those who lost their gers. 

Another wildfire outbroke in Bulgan soum of Dornod province roughly around 14:30 PM on May 1st, 2023. Local emergency management staff, Bulgan, Khulunbuir and Bayantumen soums (neighbouring soums) relevant government staff and volunteers, in total of 128 people with 13 vehicles put out the fire around 21:00 PM on May 1st. Currently, the fire is spreading across Choibalsan, Chuluunkhoroot, Gurvanzagal soums. During the response to the fires, 8 staff from the local army has been injured and one of them was severely burnt and being transported to Ulaanbaatar for medical assistance. During the fires, 24 households lost their accommodation and 3 vehicles, 36 fences and storage houses were completely burnt.

The intensifying factors of the wildfires include the strong wind (12 - 19 sec/m) and geographical character (both Sukhbaatar and Dornod are eastern provinces which are mainly grasslands). Team of 250 people including local state staff (additional forces joined from neighboring provinces which are Khentii and Sukhbaatar provinces) and community members headed by the Provincial emergency management agency worked on-site to distinguish the fire, latter, the team was strengthened by the National Rescue Brigade experts. It's currently impossible to estimate the loss of natural resources, livestock, human assets and will take more time. Known losses include the 15 households who lost their gers/houses. The State emergency commission is to allocate gers for those households. Wildfire smoke is creating a highly disturbing situation in the affected soums.

results.summary:
Flash floods have been occurring all around the country at different scales due to prolonged heavy rain fall since 28 June and until the 29 July. The rainfall is averaged to be 46-60 millimetres across the country. The flash floods and heavy rain have severely affected 1,549 households in seven (Arkhangai, Umnugovi, Orkhon, Dornogovi, Govi-Altai, Uvurkhangai, Tuv) provinces. Branch Disaster Response Teams (BDRT) in the affected areas immediately conducted situation, needs and damage assessment on the spot and exchanged information with MRCS headquarters in a timely manner.

According to the situation analysis, Umnugovi province was the most severely affected by torrential rains and devastating flash floods on 24 July. According to the local MRCS branch, the local emergency management agency received 274 rescue calls, while search and rescue operations helped 397 people. No casualties were reported.
results.name: Mongolia - Floods (Aug 2021)

results.summary: Violent gust of wind swept across the country from 14 to 15 March 2021 where the wind speed reached from 18 to 34 meter per second in Uvurkhangai, Bulgan, and Umnugovi provinces, while in Dundgovi province, the wind speed was at 22 to 40 meters per second. The wind speed also reached 16 to 28 meters per second in Govi-Altai, Bayankhongor, Arkhangai, Tuv, Khentii, Dornod, Sukhbaatar, and Dornogovi. Even though warnings had been disseminated two days prior to the event by the National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring, many who were travelling and had been herding their livestock are currently missing.
